After 3.2 million years, Lucy (AL 288-1) is becoming a world traveler. She left Ethiopia for the U.S. on Sunday and will begin a 6 year tour of the U.S. at the Houston Museum of Natural Science on Aug 31, 2007 - Apr 20, 2008. She is scheduled to make other stops in Washington, New York, Denver, and Chicago.
 
 "Lucy's Legacy: The Hidden Treasures of Ethiopia is an international exhibition organized by The Houston Museum of Natural Science in collaboration with the Ministry of Culture and Tourism of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Ethiopian Exhibition Coordinating Committee."
 
 Smithsonian Institution officials and other have objected to the transportation of the valuable and unique fossil. They certainly have a point, but nevertheless, the actual fossil will be on display. Even in Ethiopia the actual fossil has been on display only twice - the Lucy exhibit is usually a replica as the real fossil is locked in a vault.
 
 This is actually Lucy's second visit to the U.S. Her previous visit was to Cleveland and the Cleveland Museum of Natural History where Donald Johanson (who discovered Lucy in 1974) was curator of anthropology. Johanson was allowed to remove Lucy from Ethiopia because of the lack of adequate lab facilities in Ethiopia. She was returned to Ethiopia after study and description.

You mean that you can't tell by looking. Also, there are no claims that this particular fossil is a human ancestor. While this was an adult and is believed to have been a female, there is no way to tell if she actually had offspring. I'll bet you couldn't tell that by looking either. However, experienced paleoanthropologists can tell a lot by looking. You should also know that in 1996 there were 324 specimens of this species, all found at Hadar or Laetoli. Of those specimens, there are remains of 111 individuals from Hadar and 31 from Laetoli.
 
 sinjin cited some of the material from the article by which it is known that this animal was bipedal - the shape of the pelvis, the upper femur, the lower femur and the knee joint (especially clear with A.L. 129 - 1A+1B). There are also the footprints at Laetoli (3.7 million years as dated from the volcanic ash layer in which they were found). These are most certainly made by bipeds. The prints are quite similar to human footprints - the big toe is abducted.
 
 Lucy was certainly a transitional species. It is the only species from 3 to 4 million years ago to be so well represented. A. anamensis is a bit older and may have been a related or ancestral species. A. anamensis was also bipedal, at least to a great extent. However, the fossil record in the next million years is full of hominid species (8 or more) with as many as 5 or 6 living at the same time at around 2 million years ago.
